title: Why don't the Chinese write Pinyin Latin letters with tones? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m not sure what you’re asking. If you’re asking: When Chinese people write pinyin, why don’t they write tones?: CJ Chen already answered this. They do!Why don’t Chinese people stop writing characters and just write pinyin with tones?: There is not a one-to-one ratio of character to pinyin/tone. For example, “shí” (shi in second tone) means “rock,” but it also means “ten,” depending on the character used. In a sentence, you would probably be able to deduce which meaning the speaker was after, but if all the words were written this way, it would get confusing, and a lot of meaning held in the characters would be lost. Why fix something that isn’t broken (and is, in fact, beautiful)?

Pinyin Romanization does include tones. A tone mark is placed on the vowel of the syllable concerned to indicate the tone of the syllable. For example ā, the bar on top indicates the first tone; á, an ascending accent indicates the second tone; ǎ, a carrot indicates the third tone; à, and a descending accent mark indicates the forth tone.
